flashcards.english: Singular (Nĩĩ): Njũkaga (I come), Nđĩraga (I cry), Nđĩaga (I eat), Njaragia (I speak), Ngenaga (I am usually happy), Thekaga (I laugh), Thiaga (I go), Thomaga (I read). Plural (Ithuĩ): Tũkaga (we come), Tũrĩraga (we cry), Tũrĩaga (we eat), Twaragia (we speak), Tũkenaga (we are happy), Tũthekaga (we laugh), Tũthiaga (we go), Tũthomaga (we read), Tũanđĩkaga (we write)
flashcards.notes: Complete 1st person habitual conjugations. Pattern: Nĩĩ + verb-aga (I habitually...), Ithuĩ + tũ-verb-aga (we habitually...). Shows systematic pattern across 9 common verbs

flashcards.english: Now (Kahinda gaka/rĩu): Nđĩ gũkũ (I am here), Twĩ gũkũ (we are here), Wĩ gũkũ (you are here), Mwĩ gukũ (you all are here), E gũkũ (he/she is here), Me gũkũ (they are here). Earlier today (ũmũthĩ mahinda mahitũku): Nyuma gũkũ, Tuma gũkũ, Uma gũkũ, Muma gũkũ, Oima gũkũ, Moima gũkũ
flashcards.notes: Present vs recent past location. Pattern change: Nđĩ/Twĩ/Wĩ → Nyuma/Tuma/Uma (earlier today). Examples: Nđĩ gũkũ, na nđĩrarĩa nyama (I am here and I'm eating meat) vs Nyuma gũkũ na nđĩire nyama (I was here earlier and I ate meat)

examples.english: We are here and we're eating meat
We were here earlier and we ate meat

flashcards.english: Ĩno nĩ Nyaga (This is an ostrich) - Nĩ ũrĩ wona Nyaga? (Have you ever seen an ostrich?). Ĩno nĩ Huria (This is a rhino) - Nĩ marĩ mona huria? (Have they ever seen a rhino?). Ũyũ nĩ mũrũthi (This is a lion) - Nĩ mũrĩ mwona mũrũthi? (Have you all ever seen a lion?)
flashcards.notes: Experience tense pattern: Nĩ + subject + rĩ/marĩ/mũrĩ + wona/mona/mwona. Shows agreement across different persons. Thooma wanĩĩrire = read aloud
